<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Bird</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Warm-blooded, egg-laying vertebrates with wings, feathers, and beaks</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Bird_(disambiguation)" title="Bird (disambiguation)">Bird (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Birds_(disambiguation)" title="Birds (disambiguation)">Birds (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Aves" and "Avifauna" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Aves_(disambiguation)" title="Aves (disambiguation)">Aves (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Avifauna_(disambiguation)" title="Avifauna (disambiguation)">Avifauna (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

<th colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background-color: rgb(235,235,210)"><a href="/wiki/Synonym_(taxonomy)" title="Synonym (taxonomy)">Synonyms</a>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align: left">
<ul><li>Neornithes <small>Gadow, 1883</small></li></ul>
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p><b>Birds</b> are a group of <a href="/wiki/Warm-blooded" title="Warm-blooded">warm-blooded</a> <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrates</a> constituting the <a href="/wiki/Class_(biology)" title="Class (biology)">class</a> <b>Aves</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'v' in 'vie'">v</span><span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span></span>/</a></span></span>), characterised by <a href="/wiki/Feather" title="Feather">feathers</a>, toothless beaked jaws, the <a href="/wiki/Oviparity" title="Oviparity">laying</a> of <a href="/wiki/Eggshell" title="Eggshell">hard-shelled</a> eggs, a high <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolic</a> rate, a four-chambered <a href="/wiki/Heart" title="Heart">heart</a>, and a strong yet lightweight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird_skeleton" title="Bird skeleton">skeleton</a>. Birds live worldwide and range in size from the 5.5 cm (2.2 in) <a href="/wiki/Bee_hummingbird" title="Bee hummingbird">bee hummingbird</a> to the 2.8 m (9 ft 2 in) <a href="/wiki/Common_ostrich" title="Common ostrich">ostrich</a>. There are about ten thousand living species, more than half of which are <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">passerine</a>, or "perching" birds. Birds have <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#wings" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § wings">wings</span></a></dfn> whose development varies according to species; the only known groups without wings are the extinct <a href="/wiki/Moa" title="Moa">moa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elephant_bird" title="Elephant bird">elephant birds</a>. Wings, which are modified <a href="/wiki/Forelimb" title="Forelimb">forelimbs</a>, gave birds the ability to fly, although further evolution has led to the <a href="/wiki/Flightless_bird" title="Flightless bird">loss of flight in some birds</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Ratite" title="Ratite">ratites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Penguin" title="Penguin">penguins</a>, and diverse <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a> island species. The digestive and respiratory systems of birds are also uniquely adapted for flight. Some bird species of aquatic environments, particularly <a href="/wiki/Seabird" title="Seabird">seabirds</a> and some <a href="/wiki/Water_bird" title="Water bird">waterbirds</a>, have further evolved for swimming.
</p><p>Birds are <a href="/wiki/Feathered_dinosaur" title="Feathered dinosaur">feathered</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theropod" title="Theropod">theropod</a> <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur">dinosaurs</a> and constitute the <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_birds" title="Origin of birds">only known living dinosaurs</a>. Likewise, birds are considered <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a> in the modern <a href="/wiki/Cladistics" title="Cladistics">cladistic</a> sense of the term, and their closest living relatives are the <a href="/wiki/Crocodilia" title="Crocodilia">crocodilians</a>. Birds are descendants of the primitive <a href="/wiki/Avialae" title="Avialae">avialans</a> (whose members include <i><a href="/wiki/Archaeopteryx" title="Archaeopteryx">Archaeopteryx</a></i>) which first appeared about 160 million years ago (mya) in China. According to DNA evidence, modern birds (<b>Neornithes</b>) evolved in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Cretaceous" title="Middle Cretaceous">Middle</a> to <a href="/wiki/Late_Cretaceous" title="Late Cretaceous">Late Cretaceous</a>, and diversified dramatically around the time of the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a> 66 mya, which killed off the <a href="/wiki/Pterosaur" title="Pterosaur">pterosaurs</a> and all non-avian dinosaurs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-crouch2022_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-crouch2022-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_animal" title="Social animal">social species</a> pass on knowledge across generations, which is considered <a href="/wiki/Animal_culture#Examples_of_culturally_transmitted_behaviors_in_birds" title="Animal culture">a form of culture</a>. Birds are social, communicating with visual signals, calls, and <a href="/wiki/Bird_vocalization" title="Bird vocalization">songs</a>, and participating in such behaviours as <a href="/wiki/Helpers_at_the_nest" title="Helpers at the nest">cooperative breeding</a> and hunting, <a href="/wiki/Flocking_(behavior)" title="Flocking (behavior)">flocking</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mobbing_(animal_behavior)" title="Mobbing (animal behavior)">mobbing</a> of predators. The vast majority of bird species are socially (but not necessarily sexually) <a href="/wiki/Monogamy_in_animals" title="Monogamy in animals">monogamous</a>, usually for one breeding season at a time, sometimes for years, and rarely for life. Other species have breeding systems that are <a href="/wiki/Polygyny_in_animals" title="Polygyny in animals">polygynous</a> (one male with many females) or, rarely, <a href="/wiki/Polyandry_in_nature" title="Polyandry in nature">polyandrous</a> (one female with many males). Birds produce offspring by laying eggs which are fertilised through <a href="/wiki/Sexual_reproduction" title="Sexual reproduction">sexual reproduction</a>. They are usually laid in a nest and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avian_incubation" title="Avian incubation">incubated</a> by the parents. Most birds have an extended period of parental care after hatching.
</p><p>Many species of birds are economically important as food for human consumption and raw material in manufacturing, with <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">domesticated</a> and <a href="/wiki/Game_(hunting)" title="Game (hunting)">undomesticated</a> birds being important sources of eggs, meat, and feathers. <a href="/wiki/Songbird" title="Songbird">Songbirds</a>, parrots, and other species are popular as pets. <a href="/wiki/Guano" title="Guano">Guano</a> (bird excrement) is harvested for use as a fertiliser. Birds figure throughout human culture. About 120 to 130 species have become <a href="/wiki/Bird_extinction" title="Bird extinction">extinct</a> due to human activity since the 17th century, and hundreds more before then. Human activity threatens about 1,200 bird species with extinction, though efforts are underway to protect them. Recreational <a href="/wiki/Birdwatching" title="Birdwatching">birdwatching</a> is an important part of the <a href="/wiki/Ecotourism" title="Ecotourism">ecotourism</a> industry.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_and_classification">Evolution and classification</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_birds" title="Evolution of birds">Evolution of birds</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Archaeopteryx_lithographica_(Berlin_specimen).jpg"><img alt="Slab of stone with fossil bones and feather impressions" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2552" data-file-width="1888" decoding="async" height="297" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg/220px-Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg/330px-Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg/440px-Archaeopteryx_lithographica_%28Berlin_specimen%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Archaeopteryx_lithographica_(Berlin_specimen).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archaeopteryx_lithographica" title="Archaeopteryx lithographica">Archaeopteryx lithographica</a></i> is often considered the oldest known true bird.</div></div></div>
<p>The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biological_classification" title="Biological classification">classification</a> of birds was developed by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Willughby" title="Francis Willughby">Francis Willughby</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Ray" title="John Ray">John Ray</a> in their 1676 volume <i>Ornithologiae</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> modified that work in 1758 to devise the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxonomic_classification" title="Taxonomic classification">taxonomic classification</a> system currently in use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Birds are categorised as the <a href="/wiki/Class_(biology)" title="Class (biology)">biological class</a> Aves in <a href="/wiki/Linnaean_taxonomy" title="Linnaean taxonomy">Linnaean taxonomy</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_taxonomy" title="Phylogenetic taxonomy">Phylogenetic taxonomy</a> places Aves in the <a href="/wiki/Clade" title="Clade">clade</a> <a href="/wiki/Theropoda" title="Theropoda">Theropoda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theropoda_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-Theropoda-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Definition">Definition</span></h3>
<p>Aves and a sister group, the order <a href="/wiki/Crocodilia" title="Crocodilia">Crocodilia</a>, contain the only living representatives of the reptile clade <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archosauria" title="Archosauria">Archosauria</a>. During the late 1990s, Aves was most commonly defined <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetics" title="Phylogenetics">phylogenetically</a> as all descendants of the <a href="/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor">most recent common ancestor</a> of modern birds and <i><a href="/wiki/Archaeopteryx" title="Archaeopteryx">Archaeopteryx lithographica</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> However, an earlier definition proposed by <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Gauthier" title="Jacques Gauthier">Jacques Gauthier</a> gained wide currency in the 21st century, and is used by many scientists including adherents to the <i><a href="/wiki/PhyloCode" title="PhyloCode">PhyloCode</a></i>. Gauthier defined Aves to include only the <a href="/wiki/Crown_group" title="Crown group">crown group</a> of the set of modern birds. This was done by excluding most groups known only from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fossils" title="Fossils">fossils</a>, and assigning them, instead, to the broader group Avialae,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> in part to avoid the uncertainties about the placement of <i>Archaeopteryx</i> in relation to animals traditionally thought of as theropod dinosaurs.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Gauthier and de Queiroz<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gauthier&amp;dequeiroz2001_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-gauthier&amp;dequeiroz2001-12">[12]</a></sup> identified four different definitions for the same biological name "Aves", which is a problem. The authors proposed to reserve the term Aves only for the crown group consisting of the last common ancestor of all living birds and all of its descendants, which corresponds to meaning number 4 below. He assigned other names to the other groups.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<table style="border: 1px solid #ccc; background-color: white; vertical-align: middle; width: 248px; margin:0.2em 0 0.2em 1em; float:right; clear:right;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="padding: 5px">
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r984819063">.mw-parser-output table.clade{border-spacing:0;margin:0;font-size:100%;line-height:100%;border-collapse:separate;width:auto}.mw-parser-output table.clade table.clade{width:100%;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label{width:0.7em;padding:0 0.15em;vertical-align:bottom;text-align:center;border-left:1px solid;border-bottom:1px solid;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-fixed-width{overflow:hidden;text-overflow:ellipsis}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-fixed-width:hover{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label.first{border-left:none;border-right:none}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-label.reverse{border-left:none;border-right:1px solid}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel{padding:0 0.15em;vertical-align:top;text-align:center;border-left:1px solid;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel:hover{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel.last{border-left:none;border-right:none}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-slabel.reverse{border-left:none;border-right:1px solid}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-bar{vertical-align:middle;text-align:left;padding:0 0.5em;position:relative}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-bar.reverse{text-align:right;position:relative}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leaf{border:0;padding:0;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leafR{border:0;padding:0;text-align:right}.mw-parser-output table.clade td.clade-leaf.reverse{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output table.clade:hover span.linkA{background-color:yellow}.mw-parser-output table.clade:hover span.linkB{background-color:green}</style>

</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first">  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Squamate" title="Squamate">Squamates</a>  
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>  <a href="/wiki/Lizard" title="Lizard">Lizards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snake" title="Snake">snakes</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">The birds' phylogenetic relationships to major living reptile groups
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol><li>Aves can mean all <a href="/wiki/Archosaur" title="Archosaur">archosaurs</a> closer to birds than to <a href="/wiki/Crocodile" title="Crocodile">crocodiles</a> (alternately <a href="/wiki/Avemetatarsalia" title="Avemetatarsalia">Avemetatarsalia</a>)</li>
<li>Aves can mean those advanced archosaurs with feathers (alternately <a href="/wiki/Avifilopluma" title="Avifilopluma">Avifilopluma</a>)</li>
<li>Aves can mean those feathered dinosaurs that fly (alternately <a href="/wiki/Avialae" title="Avialae">Avialae</a>)</li>
<li>Aves can mean the last common ancestor of all the currently living birds and all of its descendants (a "<a href="/wiki/Crown_group" title="Crown group">crown group</a>", in this sense synonymous with <b>Neornithes</b>)</li></ol>
<p>Under the fourth definition <i>Archaeopteryx</i>, traditionally considered one of the earliest members of Aves, is removed from this group, becoming a non-avian dinosaur instead. These proposals have been adopted by many researchers in the field of palaeontology and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird_evolution" title="Bird evolution">bird evolution</a>, though the exact definitions applied have been inconsistent. Avialae, initially proposed to replace the traditional fossil content of Aves, is often used synonymously with the vernacular term "bird" by these researchers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nature_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nature-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<table style="border: 1px solid #ccc; background-color: white; vertical-align: middle; width: 248px; margin:0.2em 0 0.2em 1em; float:right; clear:right;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="padding: 5px">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade" style="font-size:75%;line-height:80%">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first">Maniraptoromorpha
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<i><a href="/wiki/Coelurus" title="Coelurus">Coelurus</a></i>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<i><a href="/wiki/Ornitholestes" title="Ornitholestes">Ornitholestes</a></i>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"><a href="/wiki/Maniraptoriformes" title="Maniraptoriformes">Maniraptoriformes</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<a href="/wiki/Ornithomimosauria" title="Ornithomimosauria">Ornithomimosauria</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"><a href="/wiki/Maniraptora" title="Maniraptora">Maniraptora</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<a href="/wiki/Alvarezsauridae" title="Alvarezsauridae">Alvarezsauridae</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"><a href="/wiki/Pennaraptora" title="Pennaraptora">Pennaraptora</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<a href="/wiki/Oviraptorosauria" title="Oviraptorosauria">Oviraptorosauria</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Paraves" title="Paraves">Paraves</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">Cladogram showing the results of a phylogenetic study by Cau, 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paleoitalia_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-paleoitalia-14">[14]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Most researchers define Avialae as branch-based clade, though definitions vary. Many authors have used a definition similar to "all <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theropod" title="Theropod">theropods</a> closer to birds than to <i><a href="/wiki/Deinonychus" title="Deinonychus">Deinonychus</a></i>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-weishampel2004_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-weishampel2004-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-senter2007_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-senter2007-16">[16]</a></sup> with <i><a href="/wiki/Troodon" title="Troodon">Troodon</a></i> being sometimes added as a second external specifier in case it is closer to birds than to <i>Deinonychus</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Avialae is also occasionally defined as an <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_nomenclature#Phylogenetic_definitions" title="Phylogenetic nomenclature">apomorphy-based clade</a> (that is, one based on physical characteristics). <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Gauthier" title="Jacques Gauthier">Jacques Gauthier</a>, who named Avialae in 1986, re-defined it in 2001 as all dinosaurs that possessed feathered wings used in flapping <a href="/wiki/Bird_flight" title="Bird flight">flight</a>, and the birds that descended from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gauthier&amp;dequeiroz2001_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-gauthier&amp;dequeiroz2001-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gauthier1986_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-gauthier1986-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite being currently one of the most widely used, the crown-group definition of Aves has been criticised by some researchers. Lee and Spencer (1997) argued that, contrary to what Gauthier defended, this definition would not increase the stability of the clade and the exact content of Aves will always be uncertain because any defined clade (either crown or not) will have few synapomorphies distinguishing it from its closest relatives. Their alternative definition is synonymous to Avifilopluma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dinosaurs_and_the_origin_of_birds">Dinosaurs and the origin of birds</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_birds" title="Origin of birds">Origin of birds</a></div>
<table style="border: 1px solid #ccc; background-color: white; vertical-align: middle; width: 248px; margin:0.2em 0 0.2em 1em; float:right; clear:right;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="padding: 5px">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade" style="font-size:75%;line-height:80%">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><a href="/wiki/Paraves" title="Paraves">Paraves</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><abbr aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;" title="Extinct">†</abbr><a href="/wiki/Scansoriopterygidae" title="Scansoriopterygidae">Scansoriopterygidae</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><abbr aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;" title="Extinct">†</abbr><i><a href="/wiki/Eosinopteryx" title="Eosinopteryx">Eosinopteryx</a></i>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eumaniraptora" title="Eumaniraptora">Eumaniraptora</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<i><a href="/wiki/Jinfengopteryx" title="Jinfengopteryx">Jinfengopteryx</a></i>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<i><a href="/wiki/Aurornis" title="Aurornis">Aurornis</a></i>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<a href="/wiki/Dromaeosauridae" title="Dromaeosauridae">Dromaeosauridae</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p>†<a href="/wiki/Troodontidae" title="Troodontidae">Troodontidae</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Avialae" title="Avialae">Avialae</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">Cladogram following the results of a phylogenetic study by Cau <i>et al.</i>, 2015<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cauetal2015_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-cauetal2015-20">[20]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="316" data-file-width="784" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp/300px-Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp/450px-Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp/600px-Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Birds_and_dinosaurs.webp" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Simplified <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree">phylogenetic tree</a> showing the relationship between modern birds and dinosaurs <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Based on fossil and biological evidence, most scientists accept that birds are a specialised subgroup of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theropod" title="Theropod">theropod</a> <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur">dinosaurs</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> and, more specifically, members of <a href="/wiki/Maniraptora" title="Maniraptora">Maniraptora</a>, a group of theropods which includes <a href="/wiki/Dromaeosauridae" title="Dromaeosauridae">dromaeosaurids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oviraptorosauria" title="Oviraptorosauria">oviraptorosaurs</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> As scientists have discovered more theropods closely related to birds, the previously clear distinction between non-birds and birds has become blurred. Recent discoveries in the <a href="/wiki/Liaoning" title="Liaoning">Liaoning</a> Province of northeast China, which demonstrate many small theropod <a href="/wiki/Feathered_dinosaur" title="Feathered dinosaur">feathered dinosaurs</a>, contribute to this ambiguity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-20140731_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20140731-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCI-20140731_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-SCI-20140731-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Anchiornis_feathers.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="2967" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Anchiornis_feathers.jpg/220px-Anchiornis_feathers.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Anchiornis_feathers.jpg/330px-Anchiornis_feathers.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Anchiornis_feathers.jpg/440px-Anchiornis_feathers.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Anchiornis_feathers.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anchiornis_huxleyi" title="Anchiornis huxleyi">Anchiornis huxleyi</a></i> is an important source of information on the early evolution of birds in the <a href="/wiki/Late_Jurassic" title="Late Jurassic">Late Jurassic</a> period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lietal2010_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-lietal2010-27">[27]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The consensus view in contemporary <a href="/wiki/Paleontology" title="Paleontology">palaeontology</a> is that the flying theropods, or <a href="/wiki/Avialae" title="Avialae">avialans</a>, are the closest relatives of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deinonychosaur" title="Deinonychosaur">deinonychosaurs</a>, which include dromaeosaurids and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Troodontid" title="Troodontid">troodontids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xiaotingia_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-Xiaotingia-28">[28]</a></sup> Together, these form a group called <a href="/wiki/Paraves" title="Paraves">Paraves</a>. Some <a href="/wiki/Basal_(phylogenetics)" title="Basal (phylogenetics)">basal</a> members of Deinonychosauria, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Microraptor" title="Microraptor">Microraptor</a></i>, have features which may have enabled them to glide or fly. The most basal deinonychosaurs were very small. This evidence raises the possibility that the ancestor of all paravians may have been <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arboreal" title="Arboreal">arboreal</a>, have been able to glide, or both.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AHTetal07_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-AHTetal07-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-xuetal2003_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-xuetal2003-30">[30]</a></sup> Unlike <i>Archaeopteryx</i> and the non-avialan feathered dinosaurs, who primarily ate meat, recent studies suggest that the first avialans were <a href="/wiki/Omnivore" title="Omnivore">omnivores</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Late_Jurassic" title="Late Jurassic">Late Jurassic</a> <i>Archaeopteryx</i> is well known as one of the first <a href="/wiki/Transitional_fossil" title="Transitional fossil">transitional fossils</a> to be found, and it provided support for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theory_of_evolution" title="Theory of evolution">theory of evolution</a> in the late 19th century. <i>Archaeopteryx</i> was the first fossil to display both clearly traditional reptilian characteristics—teeth, clawed fingers, and a long, lizard-like tail—as well as wings with flight feathers similar to those of modern birds. It is not considered a direct ancestor of birds, though it is possibly closely related to the true ancestor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mayretal2007_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-mayretal2007-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_evolution">Early evolution</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_fossil_bird_genera" title="List of fossil bird genera">List of fossil bird genera</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Confuciusornis_male.jpg"><img alt="White slab of rock left with cracks and impression of bird feathers and bone, including long paired tail feathers" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="1860" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Confuciusornis_male.jpg/220px-Confuciusornis_male.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Confuciusornis_male.jpg/330px-Confuciusornis_male.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Confuciusornis_male.jpg/440px-Confuciusornis_male.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Confuciusornis_male.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confuciusornis_sanctus" title="Confuciusornis sanctus">Confuciusornis sanctus</a></i>, a Cretaceous bird from China that lived 125 million years ago, is the oldest known bird to have a beak.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Over 40% of key traits found in modern birds evolved during the 60 million year transition from the earliest <a href="/wiki/Avemetatarsalia" title="Avemetatarsalia">bird-line archosaurs</a> to the first <a href="/wiki/Maniraptoromorpha" title="Maniraptoromorpha">maniraptoromorphs</a>, i.e. the first dinosaurs closer to living birds than to <i><a href="/wiki/Tyrannosaurus" title="Tyrannosaurus">Tyrannosaurus rex</a></i>. The loss of osteoderms otherwise common in archosaurs and acquisition of primitive feathers might have occurred early during this phase.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paleoitalia_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-paleoitalia-14">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sciencedirect_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-sciencedirect-34">[34]</a></sup> After the appearance of Maniraptoromorpha, the next 40 million years marked a continuous reduction of body size and the accumulation of <a href="/wiki/Neoteny" title="Neoteny">neotenic</a> (juvenile-like) characteristics. <a href="/wiki/Hypercarnivore" title="Hypercarnivore">Hypercarnivory</a> became increasingly less common while braincases enlarged and forelimbs became longer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paleoitalia_14-2"><a href="#cite_note-paleoitalia-14">[14]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Integument" title="Integument">integument</a> evolved into complex, pennaceous feathers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sciencedirect_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-sciencedirect-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest known paravian (and probably the earliest avialan) fossils come from the <a href="/wiki/Tiaojishan_Formation" title="Tiaojishan Formation">Tiaojishan Formation</a> of China, which has been dated to the late <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a> period (<a href="/wiki/Oxfordian_(stage)" title="Oxfordian (stage)">Oxfordian</a> stage), about 160 million years ago. The avialan species from this time period include <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anchiornis_huxleyi" title="Anchiornis huxleyi">Anchiornis huxleyi</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xiaotingia_zhengi" title="Xiaotingia zhengi">Xiaotingia zhengi</a></i>, and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aurornis_xui" title="Aurornis xui">Aurornis xui</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nature_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nature-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The well-known probable early avialan, <i>Archaeopteryx</i>, dates from slightly later Jurassic rocks (about 155 million years old) from <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>. Many of these early avialans shared unusual anatomical features that may be ancestral to modern birds, but were later lost during bird evolution. These features include enlarged claws on the second toe which may have been held clear of the ground in life, and long feathers or "hind wings" covering the hind limbs and feet, which may have been used in aerial manoeuvreing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zhengetal2013_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-zhengetal2013-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>Avialans diversified into a wide variety of forms during the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> period. Many groups retained <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symplesiomorphy" title="Symplesiomorphy">primitive characteristics</a>, such as clawed wings and teeth, though the latter were lost independently in a number of avialan groups, including modern birds (Aves).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chiappe2007_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-chiappe2007-36">[36]</a></sup> Increasingly stiff tails (especially the outermost half) can be seen in the evolution of maniraptoromorphs, and this process culminated in the appearance of the <a href="/wiki/Pygostyle" title="Pygostyle">pygostyle</a>, an ossification of fused tail vertebrae.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paleoitalia_14-3"><a href="#cite_note-paleoitalia-14">[14]</a></sup> In the late Cretaceous, about 100 million years ago, the ancestors of all modern birds evolved a more open pelvis, allowing them to lay larger eggs compared to body size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Around 95 million years ago, they evolved a better sense of smell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>A third stage of bird evolution starting with <a href="/wiki/Ornithothoraces" title="Ornithothoraces">Ornithothoraces</a> (the "bird-chested" avialans) can be associated with the refining of aerodynamics and flight capabilities, and the loss or co-ossification of several skeletal features. Particularly significant are the development of an enlarged, <a href="/wiki/Keel_(bird_anatomy)" title="Keel (bird anatomy)">keeled</a> sternum and the <a href="/wiki/Alula" title="Alula">alula</a>, and the loss of grasping hands.
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paleoitalia_14-4"><a href="#cite_note-paleoitalia-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>

<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><b>Aves</b>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last">

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>

<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>

<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">Mesozoic bird phylogeny simplified after Wang et al., 2015's phylogenetic analysis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wang2015_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wang2015-39">[39]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ichthyornis_Clean.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1309" data-file-width="1538" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ichthyornis_Clean.png/170px-Ichthyornis_Clean.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ichthyornis_Clean.png/255px-Ichthyornis_Clean.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Ichthyornis_Clean.png/340px-Ichthyornis_Clean.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ichthyornis_Clean.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Ichthyornis" title="Ichthyornis">Ichthyornis</a></i>, which lived 93 million years ago, was the first known prehistoric bird relative preserved with teeth.</div></div></div>
<p>The first large, diverse lineage of short-tailed avialans to evolve were the <a href="/wiki/Enantiornithes" title="Enantiornithes">Enantiornithes</a>, or "opposite birds", so named because the construction of their shoulder bones was in reverse to that of modern birds. Enantiornithes occupied a wide array of <a href="/wiki/Ecological_niche" title="Ecological niche">ecological niches</a>, from sand-probing shorebirds and fish-eaters to tree-dwelling forms and seed-eaters. While they were the dominant group of avialans during the Cretaceous period, enantiornithes became extinct along with many other dinosaur groups at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic">Mesozoic</a> era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chiappe2007_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-chiappe2007-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many species of the second major avialan lineage to diversify, the <a href="/wiki/Euornithes" title="Euornithes">Euornithes</a> (meaning "true birds", because they include the ancestors of modern birds), were semi-aquatic and specialised in eating fish and other small aquatic organisms. Unlike the Enantiornithes, which dominated land-based and arboreal habitats, most early euornithes lacked <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perching_bird" title="Perching bird">perching</a> adaptations and seem to have included shorebird-like species, waders, and swimming and diving species.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The latter included the superficially <a href="/wiki/Gull" title="Gull">gull</a>-like <i><a href="/wiki/Ichthyornis" title="Ichthyornis">Ichthyornis</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hesperornithiformes" title="Hesperornithiformes">Hesperornithiformes</a>, which became so well adapted to hunting fish in marine environments that they lost the ability to fly and became primarily aquatic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chiappe2007_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-chiappe2007-36">[36]</a></sup> The early euornithes also saw the development of many traits associated with modern birds, like strongly keeled breastbones, toothless, beaked portions of their jaws (though most non-avian euornithes retained teeth in other parts of the jaws).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-louchart2011_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-louchart2011-41">[41]</a></sup> Euornithes also included the first avialans to develop true <a href="/wiki/Pygostyle" title="Pygostyle">pygostyle</a> and a fully mobile fan of tail feathers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yixianornis_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-yixianornis-42">[42]</a></sup> which may have replaced the "hind wing" as the primary mode of aerial maneuverability and braking in flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zhengetal2013_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-zhengetal2013-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>A study on <a href="/wiki/Mosaic_evolution" title="Mosaic evolution">mosaic evolution</a> in the avian skull found that the <a href="/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor">last common ancestor</a> of all Neornithes might have had a beak similar to that of the modern <a href="/wiki/Hook-billed_vanga" title="Hook-billed vanga">hook-billed vanga</a> and a skull similar to that of the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_golden_oriole" title="Eurasian golden oriole">Eurasian golden oriole</a>. As both species are small aerial and canopy foraging omnivores, a similar ecological niche was inferred for this hypothetical ancestor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversification_of_modern_birds">Diversification of modern birds</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sibley%E2%80%93Ahlquist_taxonomy_of_birds" title="Sibley–Ahlquist taxonomy of birds">Sibley–Ahlquist taxonomy of birds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur_classification" title="Dinosaur classification">dinosaur classification</a></div>
<table style="border: 1px solid #ccc; background-color: white; vertical-align: middle; width: 248px; margin:0.2em 0 0.2em 1em; float:right; clear:right;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="padding: 5px">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade" style="font-size:75%;line-height:80%">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><b>Aves</b>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><a href="/wiki/Palaeognathae" title="Palaeognathae">Palaeognathae</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Struthioniformes" title="Struthioniformes">Struthioniformes</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tinamiformes" title="Tinamiformes">Tinamiformes</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"><a href="/wiki/Neognathae" title="Neognathae">Neognathae</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><a href="/wiki/Neoaves" title="Neoaves">Neoaves</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">perching</a> and other birds
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galloanserae" title="Galloanserae">Galloanserae</a> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Anseriformes" title="Anseriformes">Anseriformes</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Galliformes" title="Galliformes">Galliformes</a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">Basal divergences of modern birds<br/>based on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sibley-Ahlquist_taxonomy" title="Sibley-Ahlquist taxonomy">Sibley-Ahlquist taxonomy</a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>All modern birds lie within the <a href="/wiki/Crown_group" title="Crown group">crown group</a> Aves (alternately Neornithes), which has two subdivisions: the <a href="/wiki/Palaeognathae" title="Palaeognathae">Palaeognathae</a>, which includes the flightless <a href="/wiki/Ratite" title="Ratite">ratites</a> (such as the <a href="/wiki/Ostrich" title="Ostrich">ostriches</a>) and the weak-flying <a href="/wiki/Tinamou" title="Tinamou">tinamous</a>, and the extremely diverse <a href="/wiki/Neognathae" title="Neognathae">Neognathae</a>, containing all other birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mitchell2014_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mitchell2014-44">[44]</a></sup> These two subdivisions have variously been given the <a href="/wiki/Taxonomic_rank" title="Taxonomic rank">rank</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superorder" title="Superorder">superorder</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> cohort,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theropoda_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-Theropoda-9">[9]</a></sup> or infraclass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Depending on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alpha_taxonomy" title="Alpha taxonomy">taxonomic</a> viewpoint, the number of known living bird species varies anywhere from 9,800<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> to 10,758.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>The discovery of <i><a href="/wiki/Vegavis" title="Vegavis">Vegavis</a></i> from the <a href="/wiki/Maastrichtian" title="Maastrichtian">Maastrichtian</a>, the last stage of the Late Cretaceous proved that the diversification of modern birds started before the <a href="/wiki/Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic">Cenozoic</a> era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The affinities of an earlier fossil, the possible <a href="/wiki/Galliformes" title="Galliformes">galliform</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Austinornis" title="Austinornis">Austinornis</a> lentus</i>, dated to about 85 million years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> are still too controversial to provide a fossil evidence of modern bird diversification. In 2020, <i><a href="/wiki/Asteriornis" title="Asteriornis">Asteriornis</a></i> from the Maastrichtian was described, it appears to be a close relative of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galloanserae" title="Galloanserae">Galloanserae</a>, the earliest diverging lineage within Neognathae.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Field2020_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-Field2020-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most studies agree on a Cretaceous age for the most recent common ancestor of modern birds but estimates range from the <a href="/wiki/Early_Cretaceous" title="Early Cretaceous">Early Cretaceous</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yonezawa2017_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-Yonezawa2017-3">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-divergence_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-divergence-51">[51]</a></sup> to the latest <a href="/wiki/Late_Cretaceous" title="Late Cretaceous">Late Cretaceous</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2015_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prum2015-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kuhl2020_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-kuhl2020-4">[4]</a></sup> Similarly, there is no agreement on whether most of the early diversification of modern birds occurred before or after the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Palaeogene extinction event</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ericson_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ericson-53">[53]</a></sup> This disagreement is in part caused by a divergence in the evidence; most molecular dating studies suggests a Cretaceous <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_radiation" title="Evolutionary radiation">evolutionary radiation</a>, while fossil evidence points to a Cenozoic radiation (the so-called 'rocks' versus 'clocks' controversy). Previous attempts to reconcile molecular and fossil evidence have proved controversial,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ericson_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ericson-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> but more recent estimates, using a more comprehensive sample of fossils and a new way of calibrating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Molecular_clocks" title="Molecular clocks">molecular clocks</a>, showed that while according to some studies, modern birds originated early in the Late Cretaceous in Western <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, a pulse of diversification in all major groups occurred around the Cretaceous–Palaeogene extinction event. Modern birds expanded from West Gondwana to the Laurasia through two routes. One route was an Antarctic interchange in the Paleogene. This can be confirmed with the presence of multiple avian groups in Australia and New Zealand. The other route was probably through North America, via land bridges, during the Paleocene. This allowed the expansion and diversification of Neornithes into the Holarctic and Paleotropics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cracraft_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-cracraft-55">[55]</a></sup> On the other hand, the occurrence of <i>Asteriornis</i> in the Northern Hemisphere challenges biogeographical hypotheses of a Gondwanan origin of crown birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Field2020_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-Field2020-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classification_of_bird_orders">Classification of bird orders</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds" title="List of birds">List of birds</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cladogram" title="Cladogram">Cladogram</a> of modern bird relationships based on Braun &amp; Kimball (2021)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Braun&amp;Kimball2021_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Braun&amp;Kimball2021-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>

<td class="clade-label"><a href="/wiki/Neoaves" title="Neoaves">Neoaves</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><a href="/wiki/Mirandornithes" title="Mirandornithes">Mirandornithes</a>
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r984819063" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<table class="clade">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"> 
</td>

</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a href="/wiki/Bucerotiformes" title="Bucerotiformes">Bucerotiformes</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hornbill" title="Hornbill">hornbills</a> and relatives) <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6,_or_family_of_the_hornbills_(Plate_II)_(white_background).jpg"><img alt="A monograph of the Bucerotidæ, or family of the hornbills (Plate II) (white background).jpg" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="594" decoding="async" height="38" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg/50px-A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg/75px-A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg/100px-A_monograph_of_the_Bucerotid%C3%A6%2C_or_family_of_the_hornbills_%28Plate_II%29_%28white_background%29.jpg 2x" width="50"/></a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>

<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel"> 
</td></tr>
