<td class="clade-label"> 
</td>
<td class="clade-leaf" rowspan="2">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passeriformes" title="Passeriformes">Passeriformes</a> (passerines)<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg"><img alt="Cuvier-33-Moineau domestique.jpg" data-file-height="371" data-file-width="614" decoding="async" height="30" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg/50px-Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg/75px-Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg/100px-Cuvier-33-Moineau_domestique.jpg 2x" width="50"/></a>
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="clade-slabel last"> 
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The classification of birds is a contentious issue. <a href="/wiki/Charles_Sibley" title="Charles Sibley">Sibley</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jon_Ahlquist" title="Jon Ahlquist">Ahlquist</a>'s <i>Phylogeny and Classification of Birds</i> (1990) is a landmark work on the classification of birds,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> although it is frequently debated and constantly revised. Most evidence seems to suggest the assignment of orders is accurate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> but scientists disagree about the relationships between the orders themselves; evidence from modern bird anatomy, fossils and DNA have all been brought to bear on the problem, but no strong consensus has emerged. More recently, new fossil and molecular evidence is providing an increasingly clear picture of the evolution of modern bird orders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2015_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-Prum2015-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jarvis2014_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jarvis2014-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genomics">Genomics</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_sequenced_animal_genomes" title="List of sequenced animal genomes">list of sequenced animal genomes</a></div>
<p>As of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bird&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the <a href="/wiki/Genome" title="Genome">genome</a> had been sequenced for only two birds, the <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chicken</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Zebra_finch" title="Zebra finch">zebra finch</a>. As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bird&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>  the genomes of 542 species of birds had been completed.  At least one genome has been sequenced from every order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holmes_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-Holmes-61">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bravo_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bravo-62">[62]</a></sup> 
These include at least one species in about 90% of extant avian families (218 out of 236 families recognised by the <i>Howard and Moore Checklist</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FengStiller2020_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FengStiller2020-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Being able to sequence and compare whole genomes gives researchers many types of information, about genes, the DNA that regulates the genes, and their evolutionary history. This has led to reconsideration of some of the classifications that were based solely on the identification of protein-coding genes.  Waterbirds such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pelicans" title="Pelicans">pelicans</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flamingos" title="Flamingos">flamingos</a>, for example, may have in common specific adaptations suited to their environment that were developed independently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holmes_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-Holmes-61">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bravo_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bravo-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Distribution">Distribution</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_birds_by_region" title="Lists of birds by region">Lists of birds by region</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_by_population" title="List of birds by population">List of birds by population</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:House_sparrow04.jpg"><img alt="small bird withpale belly and breast and patterned wing and head stands on concrete" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/House_sparrow04.jpg/220px-House_sparrow04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/House_sparrow04.jpg/330px-House_sparrow04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/House_sparrow04.jpg/440px-House_sparrow04.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:House_sparrow04.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The range of the <a href="/wiki/House_sparrow" title="House sparrow">house sparrow</a> has expanded dramatically due to human activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Birds live and breed in most terrestrial habitats and on all seven continents, reaching their southern extreme in the <a href="/wiki/Snow_petrel" title="Snow petrel">snow petrel</a>'s breeding colonies up to 440 kilometres (270 mi) inland in <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The highest bird <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">diversity</a> occurs in tropical regions. It was earlier thought that this high diversity was the result of higher <a href="/wiki/Speciation" title="Speciation">speciation</a> rates in the tropics; however recent studies found higher speciation rates in the high latitudes that were offset by greater <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">extinction</a> rates than in the tropics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Many species migrate annually over great distances and across oceans; several families of birds have adapted to life both on the world's oceans and in them, and some <a href="/wiki/Seabird" title="Seabird">seabird</a> species come ashore only to breed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burger_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Burger-67">[67]</a></sup> while some <a href="/wiki/Penguin" title="Penguin">penguins</a> have been recorded diving up to 300 metres (980 ft) deep.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many bird species have established breeding populations in areas to which they have been <a href="/wiki/Introduced_species" title="Introduced species">introduced</a> by humans. Some of these introductions have been deliberate; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ring-necked_pheasant" title="Ring-necked pheasant">ring-necked pheasant</a>, for example, has been introduced around the world as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Game_bird" title="Game bird">game bird</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Others have been accidental, such as the establishment of wild <a href="/wiki/Monk_parakeet" title="Monk parakeet">monk parakeets</a> in several North American cities after their escape from captivity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Some species, including <a href="/wiki/Cattle_egret" title="Cattle egret">cattle egret</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yellow-headed_caracara" title="Yellow-headed caracara">yellow-headed caracara</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Galah" title="Galah">galah</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> have <a href="/wiki/Avian_range_expansion" title="Avian range expansion">spread naturally</a> far beyond their original ranges as <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural expansion</a> created alternative habitats although modern practices of intensive agriculture have negatively impacted farmland bird populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Anatomy_and_physiology">Anatomy and physiology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bird_anatomy" title="Bird anatomy">Bird anatomy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bird_vision" title="Bird vision">Bird vision</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Egg_tooth" title="Egg tooth">Egg tooth</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Birdmorphology.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Birdmorphology.svg/300px-Birdmorphology.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Birdmorphology.svg/450px-Birdmorphology.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Birdmorphology.svg/600px-Birdmorphology.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Birdmorphology.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>External anatomy of a bird (example: <a href="/wiki/Yellow-wattled_lapwing" title="Yellow-wattled lapwing">yellow-wattled lapwing</a>): 1 Beak, 2 Head, 3 Iris, 4 Pupil, 5 Mantle, 6 Lesser <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Covert_(feather)" title="Covert (feather)">coverts</a>, 7 Scapulars, 8 Median coverts, 9 Tertials, 10 Rump, 11 Primaries, 12 <a href="/wiki/Cloaca#Birds" title="Cloaca">Vent</a>, 13 Thigh, 14 Tibio-tarsal articulation, 15 Tarsus, 16 Foot, 17 Tibia, 18 Belly, 19 Flanks, 20 Breast, 21 Throat, 22 Wattle, 23 Eyestripe</div></div></div>
<p>Compared with other vertebrates, birds have a <a href="/wiki/Body_plan" title="Body plan">body plan</a> that shows many unusual adaptations, mostly to facilitate <a href="/wiki/Bird_flight" title="Bird flight">flight</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Skeletal_system">Skeletal system</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bird_anatomy#Skeletal_system" title="Bird anatomy">Bird_anatomy § Skeletal_system</a></div>
<p>The skeleton consists of very lightweight bones. They have large air-filled cavities (called pneumatic cavities) which connect with the <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_system" title="Respiratory system">respiratory system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The skull bones in adults are fused and do not show <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cranial_sutures" title="Cranial sutures">cranial sutures</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Orbit_(anatomy)" title="Orbit (anatomy)">orbital cavities</a> that house the eyeballs are large and separated from each other by a bony <a href="/wiki/Septum" title="Septum">septum</a> (partition). The <a href="/wiki/Vertebral_column" title="Vertebral column">spine</a> has cervical, thoracic, lumbar and caudal regions with the number of cervical (neck) vertebrae highly variable and especially flexible, but movement is reduced in the anterior <a href="/wiki/Thoracic_vertebrae" title="Thoracic vertebrae">thoracic vertebrae</a> and absent in the later vertebrae.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> The last few are fused with the <a href="/wiki/Pelvis" title="Pelvis">pelvis</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Synsacrum" title="Synsacrum">synsacrum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The ribs are flattened and the <a href="/wiki/Sternum" title="Sternum">sternum</a> is keeled for the attachment of flight muscles except in the flightless bird orders. The forelimbs are modified into wings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The wings are more or less developed depending on the species; the only known groups that lost their wings are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extinct" title="Extinct">extinct</a> <a href="/wiki/Moa" title="Moa">moa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elephant_bird" title="Elephant bird">elephant birds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Excretory_system">Excretory system</span></h3>
<p>Like the <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a>, birds are primarily <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_waste#Uricotelism" title="Metabolic waste">uricotelic</a>, that is, their <a href="/wiki/Kidney" title="Kidney">kidneys</a> extract <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nitrogenous_waste" title="Nitrogenous waste">nitrogenous waste</a> from their bloodstream and excrete it as <a href="/wiki/Uric_acid" title="Uric acid">uric acid</a>, instead of <a href="/wiki/Urea" title="Urea">urea</a> or <a href="/wiki/Ammonia" title="Ammonia">ammonia</a>, through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a <a href="/wiki/Urinary_bladder" title="Urinary bladder">urinary bladder</a> or external urethral opening and (with exception of the <a href="/wiki/Ostrich#Description" title="Ostrich">ostrich</a>) uric acid is excreted along with faeces as a semisolid waste.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coprodeum_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-coprodeum-82">[82]</a></sup> However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> They also excrete <a href="/wiki/Creatine" title="Creatine">creatine</a>, rather than <a href="/wiki/Creatinine" title="Creatinine">creatinine</a> like mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's <a href="/wiki/Cloaca#Birds" title="Cloaca">cloaca</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by <a href="/wiki/Bird_anatomy#Reproduction" title="Bird anatomy">joining cloaca</a>, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate <a href="/wiki/Pellet_(ornithology)" title="Pellet (ornithology)">pellets</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is a common but not universal feature of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Altriciality" title="Altriciality">altricial</a> <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">passerine</a> nestlings (born helpless, under constant parental care) that instead of excreting directly into the nest, they produce a <a href="/wiki/Fecal_sac" title="Fecal sac">fecal sac</a>. This is a mucus-covered pouch that allows parents to either dispose of the waste outside the nest or to recycle the waste through their own digestive system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-audubon_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-audubon-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reproductive_system">Reproductive system</span></h3>
<p>Males within <a href="/wiki/Palaeognathae" title="Palaeognathae">Palaeognathae</a> (with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(bird)" title="Kiwi (bird)">kiwis</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Anseriformes" title="Anseriformes">Anseriformes</a> (with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Screamer" title="Screamer">screamers</a>), and in rudimentary forms in <a href="/wiki/Galliformes" title="Galliformes">Galliformes</a> (but fully developed in <a href="/wiki/Cracidae" title="Cracidae">Cracidae</a>) possess a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird_penis" title="Bird penis">penis</a>, which is never present in <a href="/wiki/Neoaves" title="Neoaves">Neoaves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> The length is thought to be related to <a href="/wiki/Sperm_competition" title="Sperm competition">sperm competition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> When not copulating, it is hidden within the <a href="/wiki/Proctodeum" title="Proctodeum">proctodeum</a> compartment within the cloaca, just inside the vent. Female birds have <a href="/wiki/Female_sperm_storage" title="Female sperm storage">sperm storage</a> tubules<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> that allow sperm to remain viable long after copulation, a hundred days in some species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Sperm from multiple males may <a href="/wiki/Sperm_competition" title="Sperm competition">compete</a> through this mechanism. Most female birds have a single <a href="/wiki/Ovary" title="Ovary">ovary</a> and a single <a href="/wiki/Oviduct" title="Oviduct">oviduct</a>, both on the left side,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karger_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-karger-93">[93]</a></sup> but there are exceptions: species in at least 16 different orders of birds have two ovaries. Even these species, however, tend to have a single oviduct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karger_93-1"><a href="#cite_note-karger-93">[93]</a></sup> It has been speculated that this might be an adaptation to flight, but males have two testes, and it is also observed that the gonads in both sexes decrease dramatically in size outside the breeding season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Also terrestrial birds generally have a single ovary, as does the <a href="/wiki/Platypus" title="Platypus">platypus</a>, an egg-laying mammal. A more likely explanation is that the egg develops a shell while passing through the oviduct over a period of about a day, so that if two eggs were to develop at the same time, there would be a risk to survival.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karger_93-2"><a href="#cite_note-karger-93">[93]</a></sup> While rare, mostly abortive, <a href="/wiki/Parthenogenesis" title="Parthenogenesis">parthenogenesis</a> is not unknown in birds and eggs can be <a href="/wiki/Ploidy#Diploid" title="Ploidy">diploid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Automixis" title="Automixis">automictic</a> and results in male offspring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Birds are solely <a href="/wiki/Gonochorism" title="Gonochorism">gonochoric</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Meaning they have two sexes: either <a href="/wiki/Female" title="Female">female</a> or <a href="/wiki/Male" title="Male">male</a>. The sex of birds is determined by the <a href="/wiki/ZW_sex-determination_system" title="ZW sex-determination system">Z and W sex chromosomes</a>, rather than by the <a href="/wiki/XY_sex-determination_system" title="XY sex-determination system">X and Y chromosomes</a> present in <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a>. Male birds have two Z chromosomes (ZZ), and female birds have a W chromosome and a Z chromosome (WZ).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-3"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>In nearly all species of birds, an individual's sex is determined at fertilisation. However, one 2007 study claimed to demonstrate <a href="/wiki/Temperature-dependent_sex_determination" title="Temperature-dependent sex determination">temperature-dependent sex determination</a> among the <a href="/wiki/Australian_brushturkey" title="Australian brushturkey">Australian brushturkey</a>, for which higher temperatures during incubation resulted in a higher female-to-male <a href="/wiki/Sex_ratio" title="Sex ratio">sex ratio</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> This, however, was later proven to not be the case. These birds do not exhibit temperature-dependent sex determination, but temperature-dependent sex mortality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Respiratory_and_circulatory_systems">Respiratory and circulatory systems</span></h3>
<p>Birds have one of the most complex <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_system" title="Respiratory system">respiratory systems</a> of all animal groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-4"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Upon inhalation, 75% of the fresh air bypasses the lungs and flows directly into a posterior <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parabronchi" title="Parabronchi">air sac</a> which extends from the lungs and connects with air spaces in the bones and fills them with air. The other 25% of the air goes directly into the lungs. When the bird exhales, the used air flows out of the lungs and the stored fresh air from the posterior air sac is simultaneously forced into the lungs. Thus, a bird's lungs receive a constant supply of fresh air during both inhalation and exhalation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Sound production is achieved using the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrinx_(biology)" title="Syrinx (biology)">syrinx</a>, a muscular chamber incorporating multiple tympanic membranes which diverges from the lower end of the trachea;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Suthers_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-Suthers-101">[101]</a></sup> the trachea being elongated in some species, increasing the volume of vocalisations and the perception of the bird's size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fitch_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fitch-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>In birds, the main arteries taking blood away from the heart originate from the right <a href="/wiki/Aortic_arches" title="Aortic arches">aortic arch</a> (or pharyngeal arch), unlike in the mammals where the left aortic arch forms this part of the <a href="/wiki/Aorta" title="Aorta">aorta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-5"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The postcava receives blood from the limbs via the renal portal system. Unlike in mammals, the circulating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_blood_cells" title="Red blood cells">red blood cells</a> in birds retain their <a href="/wiki/Cell_nucleus" title="Cell nucleus">nucleus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Heart_type_and_features">Heart type and features</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3200" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg/140px-Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg/210px-Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg/280px-Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Didactic_model_of_an_avian_heart-FMVZ_USP-13_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Educational_toy" title="Educational toy">Didactic model</a> of an avian heart</div></div></div>
<p>The avian circulatory system is driven by a four-chambered, myogenic heart contained in a fibrous pericardial sac. This pericardial sac is filled with a <a href="/wiki/Serous_fluid" title="Serous fluid">serous fluid</a> for lubrication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whittow_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-Whittow-104">[104]</a></sup> The heart itself is divided into a right and left half, each with an <a href="/wiki/Atrium_(heart)" title="Atrium (heart)">atrium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ventricle_(heart)" title="Ventricle (heart)">ventricle</a>. The atrium and ventricles of each side are separated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atrioventricular_valves" title="Atrioventricular valves">atrioventricular valves</a> which prevent back flow from one chamber to the next during contraction. Being myogenic, the heart's pace is maintained by pacemaker cells found in the sinoatrial node, located on the right atrium.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sinoatrial_node" title="Sinoatrial node">sinoatrial node</a> uses calcium to cause a <a href="/wiki/Depolarization" title="Depolarization">depolarising</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Signal_transduction_pathway" title="Signal transduction pathway">signal transduction pathway</a> from the atrium through right and left atrioventricular bundle which communicates contraction to the ventricles. The avian heart also consists of muscular arches that are made up of thick bundles of muscular layers. Much like a mammalian heart, the avian heart is composed of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endocardial" title="Endocardial">endocardial</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Myocardial" title="Myocardial">myocardial</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epicardial" title="Epicardial">epicardial</a> layers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whittow_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-Whittow-104">[104]</a></sup> The atrium walls tend to be thinner than the ventricle walls, due to the intense ventricular contraction used to pump oxygenated blood throughout the body. Avian hearts are generally larger than mammalian hearts when compared to body mass. This adaptation allows more blood to be pumped to meet the high metabolic need associated with flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoagstrom_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hoagstrom-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Organisation">Organisation</span></h4>
<p>Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to <a href="/wiki/Gas_exchange" title="Gas exchange">gas exchange</a> volume than mammals. As a result, birds have more blood in their capillaries per unit of volume of lung than a mammal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoagstrom_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hoagstrom-105">[105]</a></sup> The arteries are composed of thick elastic muscles to withstand the pressure of the ventricular contractions, and become more rigid as they move away from the heart. Blood moves through the arteries, which undergo <a href="/wiki/Vasoconstriction" title="Vasoconstriction">vasoconstriction</a>, and into arterioles which act as a transportation system to distribute primarily oxygen as well as nutrients to all tissues of the body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hill_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hill-106">[106]</a></sup> As the arterioles move away from the heart and into individual organs and tissues they are further divided to increase surface area and slow blood flow. Blood travels through the arterioles and moves into the capillaries where gas exchange can occur.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Capillaries are organised into capillary beds in tissues; it is here that blood exchanges oxygen for carbon dioxide waste. In the capillary beds, blood flow is slowed to allow maximum <a href="/wiki/Diffusion" title="Diffusion">diffusion</a> of oxygen into the tissues. Once the blood has become deoxygenated, it travels through venules then veins and back to the heart. Veins, unlike arteries, are thin and rigid as they do not need to withstand extreme pressure. As blood travels through the venules to the veins a funneling occurs called <a href="/wiki/Vasodilation" title="Vasodilation">vasodilation</a> bringing blood back to the heart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hill_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hill-106">[106]</a></sup> Once the blood reaches the heart, it moves first into the right atrium, then the right ventricle to be pumped through the lungs for further gas exchange of carbon dioxide waste for oxygen. Oxygenated blood then flows from the lungs through the left atrium to the left ventricle where it is pumped out to the body.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nervous_system">Nervous system</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Nervous_system" title="Nervous system">nervous system</a> is large relative to the bird's size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-6"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The most developed part of the brain is the one that controls the flight-related functions, while the <a href="/wiki/Cerebellum" title="Cerebellum">cerebellum</a> coordinates movement and the <a href="/wiki/Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum">cerebrum</a> controls behaviour patterns, navigation, mating and <a href="/wiki/Bird_nest" title="Bird nest">nest</a> building. Most birds have a poor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olfaction" title="Olfaction">sense of smell</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> with notable exceptions including <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(bird)" title="Kiwi (bird)">kiwis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/New_World_vulture" title="New World vulture">New World vultures</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Avian_Sense_of_Smell_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Avian_Sense_of_Smell-109">[109]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tubenoses" title="Tubenoses">tubenoses</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> The avian <a href="/wiki/Visual_system" title="Visual system">visual system</a> is usually highly developed. Water birds have special flexible lenses, allowing <a href="/wiki/Accommodation_(eye)" title="Accommodation (eye)">accommodation</a> for vision in air and water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-7"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Some species also have dual <a href="/wiki/Fovea_centralis" title="Fovea centralis">fovea</a>. Birds are <a href="/wiki/Tetrachromacy" title="Tetrachromacy">tetrachromatic</a>, possessing <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> (UV) sensitive <a href="/wiki/Cone_cell" title="Cone cell">cone cells</a> in the eye as well as green, red and blue ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> They also have <a href="/wiki/Double_cone_(biology)" title="Double cone (biology)">double cones</a>, likely to mediate <a href="/wiki/Monochromacy" title="Monochromacy">achromatic vision</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bird_blink-edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="460" data-file-width="1380" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bird_blink-edit.jpg/300px-Bird_blink-edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bird_blink-edit.jpg/450px-Bird_blink-edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bird_blink-edit.jpg/600px-Bird_blink-edit.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bird_blink-edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Nictitating_membrane" title="Nictitating membrane">nictitating membrane</a> as it covers the eye of a <a href="/wiki/Masked_lapwing" title="Masked lapwing">masked lapwing</a></div></div></div>
<p>Many birds show plumage patterns in <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> that are invisible to the human eye; some birds whose sexes appear similar to the naked eye are distinguished by the presence of ultraviolet reflective patches on their feathers. Male <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_tit" title="Blue tit">blue tits</a> have an ultraviolet reflective crown patch which is displayed in courtship by posturing and raising of their nape feathers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> Ultraviolet light is also used in foraging—<a href="/wiki/Kestrel" title="Kestrel">kestrels</a> have been shown to search for prey by detecting the UV reflective urine trail marks left on the ground by rodents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> With the exception of pigeons and a few other species,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> the eyelids of birds are not used in blinking. Instead the eye is lubricated by the <a href="/wiki/Nictitating_membrane" title="Nictitating membrane">nictitating membrane</a>, a third eyelid that moves horizontally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> The nictitating membrane also covers the eye and acts as a <a href="/wiki/Contact_lens" title="Contact lens">contact lens</a> in many aquatic birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-8"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The bird <a href="/wiki/Retina" title="Retina">retina</a> has a fan shaped blood supply system called the <a href="/wiki/Pecten_oculi" title="Pecten oculi">pecten</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-9"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Eyes of most birds are large, not very round and capable of only limited movement in the orbits,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-10"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> typically 10–20°.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_2014_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-Land_2014-117">[117]</a></sup> Birds with eyes on the sides of their heads have a wide <a href="/wiki/Visual_field" title="Visual field">visual field</a>, while birds with eyes on the front of their heads, such as owls, have <a href="/wiki/Binocular_vision" title="Binocular vision">binocular vision</a> and can estimate the <a href="/wiki/Depth_of_field" title="Depth of field">depth of field</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_2014_117-1"><a href="#cite_note-Land_2014-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> The avian <a href="/wiki/Ear" title="Ear">ear</a> lacks external <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pinna_(anatomy)" title="Pinna (anatomy)">pinnae</a> but is covered by feathers, although in some birds, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Asio" title="Asio">Asio</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Horned_owl" title="Horned owl">Bubo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Scops_owl" title="Scops owl">Otus</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Owl" title="Owl">owls</a>, these feathers form tufts which resemble ears. The <a href="/wiki/Inner_ear" title="Inner ear">inner ear</a> has a <a href="/wiki/Cochlea" title="Cochlea">cochlea</a>, but it is not spiral as in mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Defence_and_intraspecific_combat">Defence and intraspecific combat</span></h3>
<p>A few species are able to use chemical defences against predators; some <a href="/wiki/Procellariiformes" title="Procellariiformes">Procellariiformes</a> can eject an unpleasant <a href="/wiki/Stomach_oil" title="Stomach oil">stomach oil</a> against an aggressor,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> and some species of <a href="/wiki/Pitohui" title="Pitohui">pitohuis</a> from <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a> have a powerful <a href="/wiki/Neurotoxin" title="Neurotoxin">neurotoxin</a> in their skin and feathers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>A lack of field observations limit our knowledge, but intraspecific conflicts are known to sometimes result in injury or death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-long_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-long-122">[122]</a></sup> The screamers (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anhimidae" title="Anhimidae">Anhimidae</a>), some jacanas (<i><a href="/wiki/Jacana_(genus)" title="Jacana (genus)">Jacana</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydrophasianus" title="Hydrophasianus">Hydrophasianus</a></i>), the spur-winged goose (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plectropterus" title="Plectropterus">Plectropterus</a></i>), the torrent duck (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Merganetta" title="Merganetta">Merganetta</a></i>) and nine species of lapwing (<i><a href="/wiki/Vanellus" title="Vanellus">Vanellus</a></i>) use a sharp spur on the wing as a weapon. The steamer ducks (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tachyeres" title="Tachyeres">Tachyeres</a></i>), geese and swans (<i><a href="/wiki/Anserinae" title="Anserinae">Anserinae</a></i>), the solitaire (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pezophaps" title="Pezophaps">Pezophaps</a></i>), sheathbills (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chionis" title="Chionis">Chionis</a></i>), some guans (<i><a href="/wiki/Crax" title="Crax">Crax</a></i>) and stone curlews (<i><a href="/wiki/Burhinus" title="Burhinus">Burhinus</a></i>) use a bony knob on the <a href="/wiki/Alula" title="Alula">alular</a> metacarpal to punch and hammer opponents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-long_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-long-122">[122]</a></sup> The jacanas <i><a href="/wiki/Actophilornis" title="Actophilornis">Actophilornis</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irediparra" title="Irediparra">Irediparra</a></i> have an expanded, blade-like radius. The extinct <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xenicibis" title="Xenicibis">Xenicibis</a></i> was unique in having an elongate forelimb and massive hand which likely functioned in combat or defence as a jointed club or flail. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cygnus_olor" title="Cygnus olor">Swans</a>, for instance, may strike with the bony spurs and bite when defending eggs or young.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-long_122-2"><a href="#cite_note-long-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Feathers.2C_plumage.2C_and_scales"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Feathers,_plumage,_and_scales">Feathers, plumage, and scales</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Feather" title="Feather">Feather</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flight_feather" title="Flight feather">Flight feather</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Down_feather" title="Down feather">Down feather</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:African_Scops_owl.jpg"><img alt="Owl with eyes closed in front of similarly coloured tree trunk partly obscured by green leaves" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/African_Scops_owl.jpg/220px-African_Scops_owl.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/African_Scops_owl.jpg/330px-African_Scops_owl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/African_Scops_owl.jpg/440px-African_Scops_owl.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:African_Scops_owl.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disruptively_patterned" title="Disruptively patterned">disruptively patterned</a> plumage of the <a href="/wiki/African_scops_owl" title="African scops owl">African scops owl</a> allows it to blend in with its surroundings.</div></div></div>
<p>Feathers are a feature characteristic of birds (though also present in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feathered_dinosaurs" title="Feathered dinosaurs">some dinosaurs</a> not currently considered to be true birds). They facilitate <a href="/wiki/Bird_flight" title="Bird flight">flight</a>, provide insulation that aids in <a href="/wiki/Thermoregulation" title="Thermoregulation">thermoregulation</a>, and are used in display, camouflage, and signalling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-11"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> There are several types of feathers, each serving its own set of purposes. Feathers are epidermal growths attached to the skin and arise only in specific tracts of skin called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pterylography" title="Pterylography">pterylae</a>. The distribution pattern of these feather tracts (pterylosis) is used in taxonomy and systematics. The arrangement and appearance of feathers on the body, called <a href="/wiki/Plumage" title="Plumage">plumage</a>, may vary within species by age, <a href="/wiki/Social_status" title="Social status">social status</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism" title="Sexual dimorphism">sex</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Plumage is regularly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moult" title="Moult">moulted</a>; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "<dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#basic_plumage" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § basic plumage">non-breeding</span></a></dfn>" plumage, or—in the <a href="/wiki/Humphrey%E2%80%93Parkes_terminology" title="Humphrey–Parkes terminology">Humphrey–Parkes terminology</a>—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey–Parkes system as "<dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#alternate_plumage" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § alternate plumage">alternate</span></a></dfn>" plumages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Moulting is annual in most species, although <a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#cite_note-32" title="Glossary of bird terms">some</a> may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, <a href="/wiki/Flight_feather" title="Flight feather">flight feathers</a> are replaced one at a time with the innermost <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#primary" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § primary">primary</span></a></dfn> being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#tertiaries" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § tertiaries">tertiaries</span></a></dfn> begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#secondaries" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § secondaries">secondaries</span></a></dfn> starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#coverts" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § coverts">coverts</span></a></dfn> are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pettingill_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-pettingill-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>A small number of species, such as ducks and geese, lose all of their flight feathers at once, temporarily becoming flightless.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-debeeretal_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-debeeretal-127">[127]</a></sup> As a general rule, the tail feathers are moulted and replaced starting with the innermost pair.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pettingill_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-pettingill-126">[126]</a></sup> Centripetal moults of tail feathers are however seen in the <a href="/wiki/Phasianidae" title="Phasianidae">Phasianidae</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> The centrifugal moult is modified in the tail feathers of <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">woodpeckers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Treecreeper" title="Treecreeper">treecreepers</a>, in that it begins with the second innermost pair of feathers and finishes with the central pair of feathers so that the bird maintains a functional climbing tail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pettingill_126-2"><a href="#cite_note-pettingill-126">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> The general pattern seen in <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">passerines</a> is that the primaries are replaced outward, secondaries inward, and the tail from centre outward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Before nesting, the females of most bird species gain a bare <a href="/wiki/Brood_patch" title="Brood patch">brood patch</a> by losing feathers close to the belly. The skin there is well supplied with blood vessels and helps the bird in incubation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red_Lory_(Eos_bornea)-6.jpg"><img alt="Red parrot with yellow bill and wing feathers in bill" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="683" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg/170px-Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg/255px-Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg/340px-Red_Lory_%28Eos_bornea%29-6.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Red_Lory_(Eos_bornea)-6.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Red_lory" title="Red lory">Red lory</a> preening</div></div></div>
<p>Feathers require maintenance and birds preen or groom them daily, spending an average of around 9% of their daily time on this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> The bill is used to brush away foreign particles and to apply <a href="/wiki/Wax" title="Wax">waxy</a> secretions from the <a href="/wiki/Uropygial_gland" title="Uropygial gland">uropygial gland</a>; these secretions protect the feathers' flexibility and act as an <a href="/wiki/Antimicrobial" title="Antimicrobial">antimicrobial agent</a>, inhibiting the growth of feather-degrading <a href="/wiki/Bacteria" title="Bacteria">bacteria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> This may be supplemented with the secretions of <a href="/wiki/Formic_acid" title="Formic acid">formic acid</a> from ants, which birds receive through a behaviour known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anting_(bird_activity)" title="Anting (bird activity)">anting</a>, to remove feather parasites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bird_anatomy#Scales" title="Bird anatomy">scales</a> of birds are composed of the same keratin as beaks, claws, and spurs. They are found mainly on the toes and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metatarsus" title="Metatarsus">metatarsus</a>, but may be found further up on the ankle in some birds. Most bird scales do not overlap significantly, except in the cases of <a href="/wiki/Kingfisher" title="Kingfisher">kingfishers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">woodpeckers</a>.
The scales of birds are thought to be <a href="/wiki/Homology_(biology)" title="Homology (biology)">homologous</a> to those of reptiles and mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flight">Flight</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bird_flight" title="Bird flight">Bird flight</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flightless_birds" title="Flightless birds">Flightless birds</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Restless_flycatcher04.jpg"><img alt="Black bird with white chest in flight with wings facing down and tail fanned and down pointing" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Restless_flycatcher04.jpg/220px-Restless_flycatcher04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Restless_flycatcher04.jpg/330px-Restless_flycatcher04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Restless_flycatcher04.jpg/440px-Restless_flycatcher04.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Restless_flycatcher04.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Restless_flycatcher" title="Restless flycatcher">Restless flycatcher</a> in the downstroke of flapping flight</div></div></div>
<p>Most birds can <a href="/wiki/Flying_and_gliding_animals" title="Flying and gliding animals">fly</a>, which distinguishes them from almost all other vertebrate classes. Flight is the primary means of locomotion for most bird species and is used for searching for food and for escaping from predators. Birds have various adaptations for flight, including a lightweight skeleton, two large flight muscles, the pectoralis (which accounts for 15% of the total mass of the bird) and the supracoracoideus, as well as a modified forelimb (<a href="/wiki/Wing" title="Wing">wing</a>) that serves as an <a href="/wiki/Airfoil" title="Airfoil">aerofoil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-12"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Wing shape and size generally determine a bird's flight style and performance; many birds combine powered, flapping flight with less energy-intensive soaring flight. About 60 extant bird species are <a href="/wiki/Flightless_bird" title="Flightless bird">flightless</a>, as were many extinct birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Flightlessness often arises in birds on isolated islands, most likely due to limited resources and the absence of <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammalian</a> land predators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Flightlessnes is almost exclusively correlated with <a href="/wiki/Island_gigantism" title="Island gigantism">gigantism</a> due to an island's inheren condition of isolation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> Although flightless, penguins use similar musculature and movements to "fly" through the water, as do some flight-capable birds such as <a href="/wiki/Auk" title="Auk">auks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shearwater" title="Shearwater">shearwaters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dipper" title="Dipper">dippers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Behaviour">Behaviour</span></h2>
<p>Most birds are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diurnal_animal" title="Diurnal animal">diurnal</a>, but some birds, such as many species of <a href="/wiki/Owl" title="Owl">owls</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nightjar" title="Nightjar">nightjars</a>, are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nocturnal" title="Nocturnal">nocturnal</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crepuscular" title="Crepuscular">crepuscular</a> (active during twilight hours), and many coastal <a href="/wiki/Wader" title="Wader">waders</a> feed when the tides are appropriate, by day or night.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diet_and_feeding">Diet and feeding</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BirdBeaksA.svg"><img alt="Illustration of the heads of 16 types of birds with different shapes and sizes of beak" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="465" decoding="async" height="512" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/BirdBeaksA.svg/170px-BirdBeaksA.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/BirdBeaksA.svg/255px-BirdBeaksA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/BirdBeaksA.svg/340px-BirdBeaksA.svg.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BirdBeaksA.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Feeding adaptations in beaks</div></div></div>
<p><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#dietary_classification_terms_(-vores)" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § dietary classification terms (-vores)">Birds' diets</span></a></dfn> are varied and often include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nectar_(plant)" title="Nectar (plant)">nectar</a>, fruit, plants, seeds, <a href="/wiki/Carrion" title="Carrion">carrion</a>, and various small animals, including other birds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-13"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digestive_system_of_birds" title="Digestive system of birds">digestive system of birds</a> is unique, with a <a href="/wiki/Crop_(anatomy)" title="Crop (anatomy)">crop</a> for storage and a <a href="/wiki/Gizzard" title="Gizzard">gizzard</a> that contains swallowed stones for grinding food to compensate for the lack of teeth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Some species such as pigeons and some psittacine species do not have a <a href="/wiki/Gallbladder" title="Gallbladder">gallbladder</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> Most birds are highly adapted for rapid digestion to aid with flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> Some migratory birds have adapted to use protein stored in many parts of their bodies, including protein from the intestines, as additional energy during migration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Battley2_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-Battley2-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>Birds that employ many strategies to obtain food or feed on a variety of food items are called generalists, while others that concentrate time and effort on specific food items or have a single strategy to obtain food are considered specialists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-14"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Avian_foraging" title="Avian foraging">Avian foraging</a> strategies can vary widely by species. Many birds <a href="/wiki/Gleaning_(birds)" title="Gleaning (birds)">glean</a> for insects, invertebrates, fruit, or seeds. Some hunt insects by suddenly attacking from a branch. Those species that seek <a href="/wiki/Pest_(organism)" title="Pest (organism)">pest</a> <a href="/wiki/Insect" title="Insect">insects</a> are considered beneficial 'biological control agents' and their presence encouraged in <a href="/wiki/Biological_pest_control" title="Biological pest control">biological pest control</a> programmes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lwa001_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-lwa001-145">[145]</a></sup> Combined, insectivorous birds eat 400–500 million metric tons of arthropods annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nectar feeders such as <a href="/wiki/Hummingbird" title="Hummingbird">hummingbirds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunbird" title="Sunbird">sunbirds</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lories_and_lorikeets" title="Lories and lorikeets">lories, and lorikeets</a> amongst others have specially adapted brushy tongues and in many cases bills designed to fit <a href="/wiki/Coevolution" title="Coevolution">co-adapted</a> flowers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(bird)" title="Kiwi (bird)">Kiwis</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shorebird" title="Shorebird">shorebirds</a> with long bills probe for invertebrates; shorebirds' varied bill lengths and feeding methods result in the separation of <a href="/wiki/Ecological_niche" title="Ecological niche">ecological niches</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-15"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Loon" title="Loon">Loons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diving_duck" title="Diving duck">diving ducks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Penguin" title="Penguin">penguins</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Auks" title="Auks">auks</a> pursue their prey underwater, using their wings or feet for propulsion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burger_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-Burger-67">[67]</a></sup> while aerial predators such as <a href="/wiki/Sulidae" title="Sulidae">sulids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingfisher" title="Kingfisher">kingfishers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tern" title="Tern">terns</a> plunge dive after their prey. <a href="/wiki/Flamingo" title="Flamingo">Flamingos</a>, three species of <a href="/wiki/Prion_(bird)" title="Prion (bird)">prion</a>, and some ducks are <a href="/wiki/Filter_feeder" title="Filter feeder">filter feeders</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geese" title="Geese">Geese</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dabbling_duck" title="Dabbling duck">dabbling ducks</a> are primarily grazers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some species, including <a href="/wiki/Frigatebird" title="Frigatebird">frigatebirds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gull" title="Gull">gulls</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Skua" title="Skua">skuas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> engage in <a href="/wiki/Kleptoparasitism" title="Kleptoparasitism">kleptoparasitism</a>, stealing food items from other birds. Kleptoparasitism is thought to be a supplement to food obtained by hunting, rather than a significant part of any species' diet; a study of <a href="/wiki/Great_frigatebird" title="Great frigatebird">great frigatebirds</a> stealing from <a href="/wiki/Masked_booby" title="Masked booby">masked boobies</a> estimated that the frigatebirds stole at most 40% of their food and on average stole only 5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> Other birds are <a href="/wiki/Scavenger" title="Scavenger">scavengers</a>; some of these, like <a href="/wiki/Vulture" title="Vulture">vultures</a>, are specialised carrion eaters, while others, like gulls, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corvid" title="Corvid">corvids</a>, or other birds of prey, are opportunists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_and_drinking">Water and drinking</span></h3>
<p>Water is needed by many birds although their mode of excretion and lack of <a href="/wiki/Sweat_gland" title="Sweat gland">sweat glands</a> reduces the physiological demands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> Some desert birds can obtain their water needs entirely from moisture in their food. They may also have other adaptations such as allowing their body temperature to rise, saving on moisture loss from evaporative cooling or panting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Seabirds can drink seawater and have <a href="/wiki/Salt_gland" title="Salt gland">salt glands</a> inside the head that eliminate excess salt out of the nostrils.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most birds scoop water in their beaks and raise their head to let water run down the throat. Some species, especially of arid zones, belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Columbidae" title="Columbidae">pigeon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estrildidae" title="Estrildidae">finch</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coliidae" title="Coliidae">mousebird</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turnicidae" title="Turnicidae">button-quail</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Otididae" title="Otididae">bustard</a> families are capable of sucking up water without the need to tilt back their heads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> Some desert birds depend on water sources and <a href="/wiki/Sandgrouse" title="Sandgrouse">sandgrouse</a> are particularly well known for their daily congregations at waterholes. Nesting sandgrouse and many plovers carry water to their young by wetting their belly feathers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> Some birds carry water for chicks at the nest in their crop or regurgitate it along with food. The pigeon family, flamingos and penguins have adaptations to produce a nutritive fluid called <a href="/wiki/Crop_milk" title="Crop milk">crop milk</a> that they provide to their chicks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Feather_care">Feather care</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Preening" title="Preening">Preening</a></div>
<p>Feathers, being critical to the survival of a bird, require maintenance. Apart from physical wear and tear, feathers face the onslaught of fungi, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ectoparasitic" title="Ectoparasitic">ectoparasitic</a> feather mites and <a href="/wiki/Bird_louse" title="Bird louse">bird lice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> The physical condition of feathers are maintained by <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#preening" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § preening">preening</span></a></dfn> often with the application of secretions from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#preen_gland" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § preen gland">preen gland</span></a></dfn>. Birds also bathe in water or dust themselves. While some birds dip into shallow water, more aerial species may make aerial dips into water and arboreal species often make use of dew or rain that collect on leaves. Birds of arid regions make use of loose soil to dust-bathe. A behaviour termed as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anting_(bird_activity)" title="Anting (bird activity)">anting</a> in which the bird encourages ants to run through their plumage is also thought to help them reduce the ectoparasite load in feathers. Many species will spread out their wings and expose them to direct sunlight and this too is thought to help in reducing fungal and ectoparasitic activity that may lead to feather damage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">Migration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bird_migration" title="Bird migration">Bird migration</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1930" data-file-width="2894" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg/220px-CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg/330px-CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg/440px-CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CanadianGeeseFlyingInVFormation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A flock of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canada_geese" title="Canada geese">Canada geese</a> in <a href="/wiki/V_formation" title="V formation">V formation</a></div></div></div>
<p>Many bird species migrate to take advantage of global differences of <a href="/wiki/Season" title="Season">seasonal</a> temperatures, therefore optimising availability of food sources and breeding habitat. These migrations vary among the different groups. Many landbirds, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shorebird" title="Shorebird">shorebirds</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waterbird" title="Waterbird">waterbirds</a> undertake annual long-distance migrations, usually triggered by the length of daylight as well as weather conditions. These birds are characterised by a breeding season spent in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">temperate</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polar_region" title="Polar region">polar regions</a> and a non-breeding season in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical" title="Tropical">tropical</a> regions or opposite hemisphere. Before migration, birds substantially increase body fats and reserves and reduce the size of some of their organs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Battley_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-Battley-166">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Klaassen_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Klaassen-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>Migration is highly demanding energetically, particularly as birds need to cross deserts and oceans without refuelling. Landbirds have a flight range of around 2,500 km (1,600 mi) and shorebirds can fly up to 4,000 km (2,500 mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-16"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> although the <a href="/wiki/Bar-tailed_godwit" title="Bar-tailed godwit">bar-tailed godwit</a> is capable of non-stop flights of up to 10,200 km (6,300 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Seabird" title="Seabird">Seabirds</a> also undertake long migrations, the longest annual migration being those of <a href="/wiki/Sooty_shearwater" title="Sooty shearwater">sooty shearwaters</a>, which nest in <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and spend the northern summer feeding in the North Pacific off Japan, <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a> and <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, an annual round trip of 64,000 km (39,800 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Other seabirds disperse after breeding, travelling widely but having no set migration route. <a href="/wiki/Albatross" title="Albatross">Albatrosses</a> nesting in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ocean" title="Southern Ocean">Southern Ocean</a> often undertake circumpolar trips between breeding seasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg"><img alt="A map of the Pacific Ocean with several coloured lines representing bird routes running from New Zealand to Korea" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="408" data-file-width="416" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg/220px-Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg/330px-Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fe/Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bar-tailed_Godwit_migration.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The routes of satellite-tagged <a href="/wiki/Bar-tailed_godwit" title="Bar-tailed godwit">bar-tailed godwits</a> migrating north from <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>. This species has the longest known non-stop migration of any species, up to 10,200 km (6,300 mi).</div></div></div>
<p>Some bird species undertake shorter migrations, travelling only as far as is required to avoid bad weather or obtain food. <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/irruptive" title="wikt:irruptive">Irruptive</a> species such as the boreal <a href="/wiki/Finch" title="Finch">finches</a> are one such group and can commonly be found at a location in one year and absent the next. This type of migration is normally associated with food availability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> Species may also travel shorter distances over part of their range, with individuals from higher latitudes travelling into the existing range of conspecifics; others undertake partial migrations, where only a fraction of the population, usually females and subdominant males, migrates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Partial migration can form a large percentage of the migration behaviour of birds in some regions; in Australia, surveys found that 44% of non-passerine birds and 32% of passerines were partially migratory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Altitudinal_migration" title="Altitudinal migration">Altitudinal migration</a> is a form of short-distance migration in which birds spend the breeding season at higher altitudes and move to lower ones during suboptimal conditions. It is most often triggered by temperature changes and usually occurs when <a href="/wiki/Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)">the normal territories</a> also become inhospitable due to lack of food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> Some species may also be nomadic, holding no fixed territory and moving according to weather and food availability. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/True_parrots" title="True parrots">Parrots</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)">family</a> are overwhelmingly neither migratory nor sedentary but considered to either be dispersive, irruptive, nomadic or undertake small and irregular migrations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ability of birds to return to precise locations across vast distances has been known for some time; in an experiment conducted in the 1950s, a <a href="/wiki/Manx_shearwater" title="Manx shearwater">Manx shearwater</a> released in <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a> in the United States returned to its colony in <a href="/wiki/Skomer" title="Skomer">Skomer</a>, in Wales within 13 days, a distance of 5,150 km (3,200 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Birds navigate during migration using a variety of methods. For <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diurnal_animal" title="Diurnal animal">diurnal</a> migrants, the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">sun</a> is used to navigate by day, and a stellar compass is used at night. Birds that use the sun compensate for the changing position of the sun during the day by the use of an <a href="/wiki/Chronobiology" title="Chronobiology">internal clock</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-17"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Orientation with the stellar compass depends on the position of the <a href="/wiki/Constellation" title="Constellation">constellations</a> surrounding <a href="/wiki/Polaris" title="Polaris">Polaris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> These are backed up in some species by their ability to sense the Earth's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geomagnetism" title="Geomagnetism">geomagnetism</a> through specialised <a href="/wiki/Photoreceptor_cell" title="Photoreceptor cell">photoreceptors</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communication">Communication</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird_vocalisation" title="Bird vocalisation">Bird vocalisation</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096940132">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right listen noprint">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Troglodytes_aedon_-_House_Wren_-_XC79974.ogg" title="File:Troglodytes aedon - House Wren - XC79974.ogg">Bird song</a></div>
