<div class="description">Song of the <a href="/wiki/House_wren" title="House wren">house wren</a>, a common North American songbird</div></div><hr/><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Tooth-billed_Catbird_audio09.ogg" title="File:Tooth-billed Catbird audio09.ogg">Mimicry</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="23" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Tooth-billed_Catbird_audio09.ogg" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="134571" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (135 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ea/Tooth-billed_Catbird_audio09.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="226488" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/ea/Tooth-billed_Catbird_audio09.ogg/Tooth-billed_Catbird_audio09.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/></audio></div>

<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Picidae_pecking_on_wood.ogg" title="File:Picidae pecking on wood.ogg">Drumming</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="3" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Picidae_pecking_on_wood.ogg" id="mwe_player_2" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="137272" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a2/Picidae_pecking_on_wood.ogg/Picidae_pecking_on_wood.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><source data-bandwidth="257180" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (257 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a2/Picidae_pecking_on_wood.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/></audio></div>
<div class="description">A <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">woodpecker</a> drumming on wood</div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr/><i class="selfreference">Problems playing these files? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div><p>Birds <a href="/wiki/Animal_communication" title="Animal communication">communicate</a> primarily using visual and auditory signals. Signals can be interspecific (between species) and intraspecific (within species).
</p><p>Birds sometimes use plumage to assess and assert social dominance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> to display breeding condition in sexually selected species, or to make threatening displays, as in the <a href="/wiki/Sunbittern" title="Sunbittern">sunbittern</a>'s mimicry of a large predator to ward off <a href="/wiki/Hawk" title="Hawk">hawks</a> and protect young chicks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg"><img alt="Large brown patterned ground bird with outstretched wings each with a large spot in the centre" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="480" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg/220px-Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg/330px-Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg/440px-Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stavenn_Eurypiga_helias_00.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The startling display of the <a href="/wiki/Sunbittern" title="Sunbittern">sunbittern</a> mimics a large predator.</div></div></div><p>Visual communication among birds may also involve ritualised displays, which have developed from non-signalling actions such as preening, the adjustments of feather position, pecking, or other behaviour. These displays may signal aggression or submission or may contribute to the formation of pair-bonds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-18"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> The most elaborate displays occur during courtship, where "dances" are often formed from complex combinations of many possible component movements;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> males' breeding success may depend on the quality of such displays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bird_vocalization" title="Bird vocalization">Bird calls and songs</a>, which are produced in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrinx_(biology)" title="Syrinx (biology)">syrinx</a>, are the major means by which birds communicate with <a href="/wiki/Sound" title="Sound">sound</a>. This communication can be very complex; some species can operate the two sides of the syrinx independently, allowing the simultaneous production of two different songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Suthers_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-Suthers-101">[101]</a></sup>
Calls are used for a variety of purposes, including mate attraction,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-19"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> evaluation of potential mates,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> bond formation, the claiming and maintenance of territories,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-20"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> the identification of other individuals (such as when parents look for chicks in colonies or when mates reunite at the start of breeding season),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> and the warning of other birds of potential predators, sometimes with specific information about the nature of the threat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> Some birds also use mechanical sounds for auditory communication. The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coenocorypha" title="Coenocorypha">Coenocorypha</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Snipe" title="Snipe">snipes</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> drive air through their feathers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miskelly_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-Miskelly-186">[186]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">woodpeckers</a> drum for long-distance communication,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DodenhoffStark2001_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-DodenhoffStark2001-187">[187]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Palm_cockatoo" title="Palm cockatoo">palm cockatoos</a> use tools to drum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flocking_and_other_associations">Flocking and other associations</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg"><img alt="massive flock of tiny birds seen from distance so that birds appear as specks" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg/220px-Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg/330px-Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg/440px-Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Red-billed_quelea_flocking_at_waterhole.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Red-billed_quelea" title="Red-billed quelea">Red-billed queleas</a>, the most numerous species of wild bird,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flycatcher_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-flycatcher-189">[189]</a></sup> form enormous flocks – sometimes tens of thousands strong.</div></div></div>
<p>While some birds are essentially territorial or live in small family groups, other birds may form large <a href="/wiki/Flock_(birds)" title="Flock (birds)">flocks</a>. The principal benefits of flocking are <a href="/wiki/Safety_in_numbers" title="Safety in numbers">safety in numbers</a> and increased foraging efficiency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-21"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Defence against predators is particularly important in closed habitats like forests, where <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ambush_predation" title="Ambush predation">ambush predation</a> is common and multiple eyes can provide a valuable <a href="/wiki/Early_warning_system" title="Early warning system">early warning system</a>. This has led to the development of many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixed-species_feeding_flock" title="Mixed-species feeding flock">mixed-species feeding flocks</a>, which are usually composed of small numbers of many species; these flocks provide safety in numbers but increase potential competition for resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Costs of flocking include bullying of socially subordinate birds by more dominant birds and the reduction of feeding efficiency in certain cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>Birds sometimes also form associations with non-avian species. Plunge-diving <a href="/wiki/Seabird" title="Seabird">seabirds</a> associate with <a href="/wiki/Dolphin" title="Dolphin">dolphins</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tuna" title="Tuna">tuna</a>, which push shoaling fish towards the surface.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AU_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-AU-192">[192]</a></sup> Some species of <a href="/wiki/Hornbill" title="Hornbill">hornbills</a> have a <a href="/wiki/Mutualism_(biology)" title="Mutualism (biology)">mutualistic relationship</a> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dwarf_mongoose" title="Dwarf mongoose">dwarf mongooses</a>, in which they forage together and warn each other of nearby <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birds_of_prey" title="Birds of prey">birds of prey</a> and other predators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resting_and_roosting">Resting and roosting</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Roosting" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Roost_(disambiguation)" title="Roost (disambiguation)">Roost</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Caribbean_Flamingo2_(Phoenicopterus_ruber)_(0424)_-_Relic38.jpg"><img alt="Pink flamingo with grey legs and long neck pressed against body and head tucked under wings" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2460" data-file-width="3120" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg/220px-Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg/330px-Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg/440px-Caribbean_Flamingo2_%28Phoenicopterus_ruber%29_%280424%29_-_Relic38.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Caribbean_Flamingo2_(Phoenicopterus_ruber)_(0424)_-_Relic38.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Many birds, like this <a href="/wiki/American_flamingo" title="American flamingo">American flamingo</a>, tuck their head into their back when sleeping.</div></div></div>
<p>The high metabolic rates of birds during the active part of the day is supplemented by rest at other times. Sleeping birds often use a type of sleep known as vigilant sleep, where periods of rest are interspersed with quick eye-opening "peeks", allowing them to be sensitive to disturbances and enable rapid escape from threats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Swift_(bird)" title="Swift (bird)">Swifts</a> are believed to be able to sleep in flight and radar observations suggest that they orient themselves to face the wind in their roosting flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> It has been suggested that there may be certain kinds of sleep which are possible even when in flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some birds have also demonstrated the capacity to fall into <a href="/wiki/Slow-wave_sleep" title="Slow-wave sleep">slow-wave sleep</a> one <a href="/wiki/Cerebral_hemisphere" title="Cerebral hemisphere">hemisphere</a> of the brain at a time. The birds tend to exercise this ability depending upon its position relative to the outside of the flock. This may allow the eye opposite the sleeping hemisphere to remain vigilant for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Predator" title="Predator">predators</a> by viewing the outer margins of the flock. This adaptation is also known from <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">marine mammals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Communal_roosting" title="Communal roosting">Communal roosting</a> is common because it lowers the <a href="/wiki/Thermoregulation" title="Thermoregulation">loss of body heat</a> and decreases the risks associated with predators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> Roosting sites are often chosen with regard to thermoregulation and safety.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> Unusual mobile roost sites include large herbivores on the African savanna that are used by <a href="/wiki/Oxpecker" title="Oxpecker">oxpeckers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many sleeping birds bend their heads over their backs and tuck their <a href="/wiki/Beak" title="Beak">bills</a> in their back feathers, although others place their beaks among their breast feathers. Many birds rest on one leg, while some may pull up their legs into their feathers, especially in cold weather. <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">Perching birds</a> have a tendon-locking mechanism that helps them hold on to the perch when they are asleep. Many ground birds, such as quails and pheasants, roost in trees. A few parrots of the genus <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loriculus" title="Loriculus">Loriculus</a></i> roost hanging upside down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Hummingbird" title="Hummingbird">hummingbirds</a> go into a nightly state of <a href="/wiki/Torpor" title="Torpor">torpor</a> accompanied with a reduction of their metabolic rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Adaptation" title="Adaptation">physiological adaptation</a> shows in nearly a hundred other species, including <a href="/wiki/Owlet-nightjar" title="Owlet-nightjar">owlet-nightjars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nightjar" title="Nightjar">nightjars</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Woodswallow" title="Woodswallow">woodswallows</a>. One species, the <a href="/wiki/Common_poorwill" title="Common poorwill">common poorwill</a>, even enters a state of <a href="/wiki/Hibernation" title="Hibernation">hibernation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> Birds do not have sweat glands, but can lose water directly through the skin, and they may cool themselves by moving to shade, standing in water, panting, increasing their surface area, fluttering their throat or using special behaviours like <a href="/wiki/Urohidrosis" title="Urohidrosis">urohidrosis</a> to cool themselves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Breeding">Breeding</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Category:Avian_sexuality" title="Category:Avian sexuality">Category:Avian sexuality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Animal_sexual_behaviour#Birds" title="Animal sexual behaviour">Animal sexual behaviour § Birds</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seabird_breeding_behaviour" title="Seabird breeding behaviour">Seabird breeding behaviour</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sexual_selection_in_birds" title="Sexual selection in birds">Sexual selection in birds</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_systems">Social systems</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg"><img alt="Bird faces up with green face, black breast and pink lower body. Elaborate long feathers on the wings and tail." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg/220px-Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg/330px-Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg/440px-Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Raggiana_Bird-of-Paradise_wild_5.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Like others of its family, the male <a href="/wiki/Raggiana_bird-of-paradise" title="Raggiana bird-of-paradise">Raggiana bird-of-paradise</a> has elaborate breeding plumage used to impress females.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Ninety-five per cent of bird species are socially monogamous. These species pair for at least the length of the breeding season or—in some cases—for several years or until the death of one mate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Monogamy allows for both <a href="/wiki/Paternal_care" title="Paternal care">paternal care</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parental_investment" title="Parental investment">biparental care</a>, which is especially important for species in which care from both the female and the male parent is required in order to successfully rear a brood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> Among many socially monogamous species, <a href="/wiki/Extra-pair_copulation" title="Extra-pair copulation">extra-pair copulation</a> (infidelity) is common.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> Such behaviour typically occurs between dominant males and females paired with subordinate males, but may also be the result of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced_copulation" title="Forced copulation">forced copulation</a> in ducks and other <a href="/wiki/Anatidae" title="Anatidae">anatids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>For females, possible benefits of extra-pair copulation include getting better genes for her offspring and insuring against the possibility of infertility in her mate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> Males of species that engage in extra-pair copulations will closely guard their mates to ensure the parentage of the offspring that they raise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other mating systems, including <a href="/wiki/Polygyny" title="Polygyny">polygyny</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polyandry" title="Polyandry">polyandry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polygamy" title="Polygamy">polygamy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polygynandry" title="Polygynandry">polygynandry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Promiscuity" title="Promiscuity">promiscuity</a>, also occur.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-22"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Polygamous breeding systems arise when females are able to raise broods without the help of males.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-23"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Mating systems vary across bird families<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> but variations within species are thought to be driven by environmental conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>Breeding usually involves some form of courtship display, typically performed by the male.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> Most displays are rather simple and involve some type of <a href="/wiki/Bird_vocalization" title="Bird vocalization">song</a>. Some displays, however, are quite elaborate. Depending on the species, these may include wing or tail drumming, dancing, aerial flights, or communal <a href="/wiki/Lek_mating" title="Lek mating">lekking</a>. Females are generally the ones that drive partner selection,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> although in the polyandrous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phalaropes" title="Phalaropes">phalaropes</a>, this is reversed: plainer males choose brightly coloured females.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courtship_feeding" title="Courtship feeding">Courtship feeding</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Billing_(birds)" title="Billing (birds)">billing</a> and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_bird_terms#allopreening" title="Glossary of bird terms"><span class="glossary-link" style="color:inherit;" title="See entry at: Glossary of bird terms § allopreening">allopreening</span></a></dfn> are commonly performed between partners, generally after the birds have paired and mated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homosexuality_in_animals#Birds" title="Homosexuality in animals">Homosexual behaviour has been observed</a> in males or females in numerous species of birds, including copulation, pair-bonding, and joint parenting of chicks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> Over 130 avian species around the world engage in sexual interactions between the same sex or homosexual behaviours. "Same-sex courtship activities may involve elaborate displays, synchronized dances, gift-giving ceremonies, or behaviors at specific display areas including bowers, arenas, or leks."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Territories.2C_nesting_and_incubation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Territories,_nesting_and_incubation">Territories, nesting and incubation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Bird_nest" title="Bird nest">Bird nest</a></div>
<p>Many birds actively defend a territory from others of the same species during the breeding season; maintenance of territories protects the food source for their chicks. Species that are unable to defend feeding territories, such as <a href="/wiki/Seabird" title="Seabird">seabirds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swift_(bird)" title="Swift (bird)">swifts</a>, often breed in <a href="/wiki/Bird_colony" title="Bird colony">colonies</a> instead; this is thought to offer protection from predators. Colonial breeders defend small nesting sites, and competition between and within species for nesting sites can be intense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>All birds lay <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amniotic_egg" title="Amniotic egg">amniotic eggs</a> with hard shells made mostly of <a href="/wiki/Calcium_carbonate" title="Calcium carbonate">calcium carbonate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-24"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> Hole and burrow nesting species tend to lay white or pale eggs, while open nesters lay <a href="/wiki/Camouflage" title="Camouflage">camouflaged</a> eggs. There are many exceptions to this pattern, however; the ground-nesting <a href="/wiki/Nightjar" title="Nightjar">nightjars</a> have pale eggs, and camouflage is instead provided by their plumage. Species that are victims of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brood_parasites" title="Brood parasites">brood parasites</a> have varying egg colours to improve the chances of spotting a parasite's egg, which forces female parasites to match their eggs to those of their hosts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg"><img alt="Yellow weaver (bird) with black head hangs an upside-down nest woven out of grass fronds." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="681" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg/220px-Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg/330px-Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg/440px-Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Golden-backed_Weaver.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Male <a href="/wiki/Golden-backed_weaver" title="Golden-backed weaver">golden-backed weavers</a> construct elaborate suspended nests out of grass.</div></div></div>
<p>Bird eggs are usually laid in a <a href="/wiki/Bird_nest" title="Bird nest">nest</a>. Most species create somewhat elaborate nests, which can be cups, domes, plates, mounds, or burrows.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hansell_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hansell-223">[223]</a></sup> Some bird nests can be a simple scrape, with minimal or no lining; most seabird and wader nests are no more than a scrape on the ground. Most birds build nests in sheltered, hidden areas to avoid predation, but large or colonial birds—which are more capable of defence—may build more open nests. During nest construction, some species seek out plant matter from plants with parasite-reducing toxins to improve chick survival,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> and feathers are often used for nest insulation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hansell_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hansell-223">[223]</a></sup> Some bird species have no nests; the cliff-nesting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_guillemot" title="Common guillemot">common guillemot</a> lays its eggs on bare rock, and male <a href="/wiki/Emperor_penguin" title="Emperor penguin">emperor penguins</a> keep eggs between their body and feet. The absence of nests is especially prevalent in open habitat ground-nesting species where any addition of nest material would make the nest more conspicuous. Many ground nesting birds lay a clutch of eggs that hatch synchronously, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precocial" title="Precocial">precocial</a> chicks led away from the nests (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nidifugous" title="Nidifugous">nidifugous</a>) by their parents soon after hatching.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg"><img alt="Nest made of straw with five white eggs and one grey speckled egg" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg/220px-Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg/330px-Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg/440px-Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eastern_Phoebe-nest-Brown-headed-Cowbird-egg.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Nest of an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_phoebe" title="Eastern phoebe">eastern phoebe</a> that has been parasitised by a <a href="/wiki/Brown-headed_cowbird" title="Brown-headed cowbird">brown-headed cowbird</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Egg_incubation" title="Egg incubation">Incubation</a>, which regulates temperature for chick development, usually begins after the last egg has been laid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-25"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup> In monogamous species incubation duties are often shared, whereas in polygamous species one parent is wholly responsible for incubation. Warmth from parents passes to the eggs through <a href="/wiki/Brood_patch" title="Brood patch">brood patches</a>, areas of bare skin on the abdomen or breast of the incubating birds. Incubation can be an energetically demanding process; adult albatrosses, for instance, lose as much as 83 grams (2.9 oz) of body weight per day of incubation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> The warmth for the incubation of the eggs of <a href="/wiki/Megapode" title="Megapode">megapodes</a> comes from the sun, decaying vegetation or volcanic sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> Incubation periods range from 10 days (in <a href="/wiki/Woodpecker" title="Woodpecker">woodpeckers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuckoo" title="Cuckoo">cuckoos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">passerine</a> birds) to over 80 days (in albatrosses and <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(bird)" title="Kiwi (bird)">kiwis</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gill_76-26"><a href="#cite_note-Gill-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>The diversity of characteristics of birds is great, sometimes even in closely related species. Several avian characteristics are compared in the table below.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnAge_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-AnAge-228">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ADW_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-ADW-229">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<tbody><tr>
